channel.title: Bloomberg Politics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Crypto Bill Poised for Resurrection After Democrats Hail Changes
item.description: Crypto-friendly Senate Democrats moved closer to reviving stablecoin legislation sought by the industry after bipartisan negotiators agreed to assorted revisions, including tightened restrictions on money laundering, foreign issuers and technology companies.
item.dc:creator: Teresa Xie, Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: Senator Angela Alsobrooks, a Democrat from Maryland, speaks during a Senate Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions Committee confirmation hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, Feb. 27, 2025. Keith Sonderling has been serving as a senior adviser to the Acting Secretary of Labor Vince Micone since Trump took office last month.

item.title: Ukraine Ceasefire Prospects Dim as Calls for New Sanctions Grow
item.description: Hopes faded for a Ukraine ceasefire after Vladimir Putin sent a low-level delegation to talks in Turkey, while attention shifted to bids on Capitol Hill for fresh sanctions to bring the Russian leader to the negotiating table.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Drozdiak, Jamie Tarabay

media:content.media:description: Ukraine’s Andrii Sybiha, left, Lindsey Graham and Marco Rubio in Antalya, Turkey, on May 15.

item.title: Sparring Over SALT in Trump Tax Bill Threatens Fast Passage
item.description: Republican infighting in the US House is threatening to sink President Donald Trump’s legislative agenda as competing factions spar over details of the giant tax bill.
item.dc:creator: Jarrell Dillard, Emily Birnbaum, Ken Tran

media:content.media:description: Representative Jason Smith

item.title: Trump Argues Immunity in Fight With Truth Social Co-Founders
item.description: Lawyers for President Donald Trump argued to a Delaware judge that a suit against him by the co-founders of his Truth Social platform should be dismissed or put on hold because he has immunity from such litigation while in office.
item.dc:creator: Jef Feeley, Sabrina Willmer

media:content.media:description: The Truth Social logo on a laptop arranged in New York, US, on Friday, March 22, 2024. Shareholders of Digital World Acquisition Corp., a publicly traded shell company, approved a deal to merge with the Trump's media business in a Friday vote. That means Trump Media & Technology Group, whose flagship product is social networking site Truth Social, will soon begin trading on the Nasdaq stock market, reported the AP. Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump’s Cuts at Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac May Slow Housing Recovery, Report Says
item.description: The Trump administration’s cuts to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government-sponsored mortgage giants, may put a damper on the housing market as it becomes harder to obtain some types of home loans, according to a report from Bloomberg Intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Scott Carpenter

item.title: World Economic Forum Courts Lagarde as Its Next Leader After Founder’s Abrupt Exit
item.description: Klaus Schwab’s abrupt departure from the World Economic Forum, the influential organization he founded and led for more than half a century, has complicated carefully laid plans to persuade Christine Lagarde to assume the helm in a seamless transition, according to people familiar with the discussions.
item.dc:creator: Hugo Miller, Jan-Henrik Foerster, Bastian Benrath-Wright

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde

item.title: Tallying Up the Price for Trump’s ‘One Big, Beautiful Bill’
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Today, senior economy reporter Enda Curran looks at the varying estimates of the cost for the Republican tax-cut bill. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Enda Curran

item.title: Supreme Court Wary of Letting Trump Citizenship Curbs Start
item.description: The US Supreme Court signaled it is wary of letting President Donald Trump start to restrict birthright citizenship as the justices debated how much power federal judges should have to block controversial White House policies nationwide.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: Demonstrators outside the US Supreme Court during oral arguments in Washington on May 15.

item.title: Ontario to Sell More Debt Abroad as Deficit, Spending Grow
item.description: Ontario plans to borrow C$59.8 billion ($42.7 billion) to fund a larger budget deficit and spending on highways and other infrastructure, and expects more of it will come from foreign currency bond sales.
item.dc:creator: Chunzi Xu

media:content.media:description: Peter Bethlenfalvy, Ontario's finance minister, speaks during a media event at a Honda of Canada Manufacturing plant in Alliston, Ontario, Canada, on Thursday, April 25, 2024. Honda Motor Co. will spend C$15 billion ($11 billion) to build out its electric-vehicle supply chain in Canada, with billions of dollars of financial aid from government, as the Japanese automaker seeks to tap long-term demand in the region.

item.title: Trade War Brings Ontario Budget Deficit to Near Pandemic Levels
item.description: Ontario’s budget shortfall is expected to reach its highest level since the beginning of the Covid-19 pandemic as the effects of the trade war hurt economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Hughes

media:content.media:description: Doug Ford, Ontario's premier, arrives at the First Minister's Meeting at the Canadian War Museum in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, on Friday, March 21, 2025. Mark Carney, Canada's prime minister, is set to call a national election within days, seeking his own mandate from voters at a time when the country's businesses have been shaken by a trade war with the US.

item.title: Pentagon Says It Has Crafted Initial Plan for ‘Golden Dome’ Defense System
item.description: The Pentagon has developed a draft architecture and plan to implement the proposed “Golden Dome” air and missile defense system, its spokesman said, as questions mount about the Trump administration’s ambitious project.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Capaccio

media:content.media:description: The Pentagon building in Arlington, Virginia, US, on Friday, April 14, 2023. The FBI yesterday arrested a 21-year-old Air National Guardsman in connection with the leak of highly classified documents including maps, intelligence updates and the assessment of Russia's war in Ukraine after the Pentagon and Justice Department launched investigations into the leak.

item.title: Trump Touts $200 Billion in UAE Deals in Wrapping Mideast Trip
item.description: US President Donald Trump has secured $200 billion in deals during a visit to the United Arab Emirates, according to the White House, including agreements involving artificial intelligence that will boost the Gulf nation’s technological ambitions.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy, Kate Sullivan

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump arrives at the Qasr Al-Watan, Palace of the Nation, in Abu Dhabi on May 15.

item.title: Voice of America Building Is Latest Federal Property Up for Sale
item.description: President Donald Trump’s administration is putting the home of Voice of America up for possible sale — the latest in a series of high-profile buildings placed on a list for “accelerated disposal” as it moves to reduce the government’s real estate footprint.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Korte

media:content.media:description: The Voice of America headquarters in Washington, DC, US, on Saturday, March 15, 2025. President Donald Trump on Friday signed an executive order aimed at reducing the scope of eight federal agencies as part of his campaign to downsize the US government, including the US Agency for Global Media, which oversees Voice of America.

item.title: Ukrainian Charged in Arson Attacks Targeting UK Premier Starmer
item.description: A Ukrainian national has been charged with three counts of arson after a series of fires at properties linked to UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham

media:content.media:description: A forensics officer is seen in Kentish Town, north London. Police are investigating a fire at Sir Keir Starmer's house in north London. Picture date: Monday May 12, 2025. (Photo by James Manning/PA Images via Getty Images)

item.title: War Over Energy Tax Credits Divides GOP in Headache for Speaker
item.description: Moderate House Republicans are lobbying House Speaker Mike Johnson to lessen cuts to several clean energy tax credits in the broad tax and spending bill prior to the GOP’s plans to bring it to the floor next week.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: Jen Kiggans

item.title: Trump’s Pledge to Lift Syrian Sanctions Faces a Complex Road
item.description: US President Donald Trump says he’s ready to ease sanctions on Syria. He won’t be able to do it quickly.
item.dc:creator: Sam Dagher

media:content.media:description: Buildings destroyed during the war in Harasta, on the outskirts of Damascus, Syria. Photographer: David Lombeida/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Will Seek 180-Day Waiver to Congress Sanctions on Syria
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio said the Trump administration will offer Syria initial economic relief by seeking a 180-day waiver to sanctions imposed by Congress, with the longer-term goal of removing the restrictions entirely.
item.dc:creator: Nick Wadhams

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump outside the West Wing of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, May 8, 2025. Trump hailed the election of Cardinal Robert Francis Prevost as the pope, the first US national ever to be head of the Catholic Church, and said he looked forward to meeting him.

item.title: Italy and Albania to Host Summit and Deepen Defense, Energy Ties
item.description: The Italian and Albanian prime ministers plan to hold their first high-level intergovernmental summit in Italy by the end of the year, according to a draft joint statement seen by Bloomberg News.
item.dc:creator: Donato Paolo Mancini, Gresa Kraja

media:content.media:description: Italian Prime Minister, Giorgia Meloni receives the Prime Minister of the Republic of Albania, Edi Rama at Palazzo Chigi to draw up a memorandum of understanding between Italy and Albania on the management of migrant flows. Rome (Italy), November 6th, 2023 (Photo by Massimo Di Vita/Archivio Massimo Di Vita/Mondadori Portfolio via Getty Images)

item.title: US Seeks to Block Loans to China State Companies in Colombia
item.description: The US said it will seek to block loans from multilateral lenders to Chinese state companies operating in Colombia.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Medina

media:content.media:description: Xi Jinping shakes hands with Gustavo Petro after delivering a speech for the opening ceremony of the Fourth Ministerial Meeting of the Forum of China and Community of Latin American and Caribbean States at China National Convention Center in Beijing, on May 13.

item.title: France and Spain Want to Impose Age Limits on Social Media Networks
item.description: France, Spain and Greece are pushing for mandatory age restrictions for users of social networks including Meta Platforms Inc.’s Facebook and Elon Musk’s X, according to a document seen by Bloomberg.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro

item.title: Newark Mayor Baraka Could Face July Trial in Trespassing Case
item.description: Ras Baraka, the mayor of Newark, New Jersey, could face a July trial for trespassing after his arrest at a private detention facility that would help the Trump administration’s mass deportation efforts.
item.dc:creator: David Voreacos

media:content.media:description: NEWARK, NEW JERSEY - MAY 15: Ras Baraka, Mayor of Newark, speaks to the media and supporters after exiting the courthouse on May 15, 2025 in Newark, New Jersey. Baraka appeared in federal court for a status conference on the Trump administration's charge that he trespassed last week at Delaney Hall, an ICE immigration detention center in Newark. (Photo by Stephanie Keith/Getty Images)

item.title: US-China Trade Clash Risks Making Europe Dumping Ground for Cheap Goods
item.description: China’s widening trade surplus with the European Union is fueling fresh concerns that the 27-nation bloc risks becoming a dumping ground for cheap goods in the volatile tariff confrontation between Washington and Beijing.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger, William Horobin

item.title: Qatar’s Wealth Fund Plans $500 Billion US Push Over Next Decade
item.description: During his first 15 years at Qatar Investment Authority, Mohammed Al Sowaidi helped establish its US presence and scout opportunities. Now, as head of the $524 billion state-backed entity, he’s pledging to invest an amount nearly equal to the fund’s current size, as part of a major commitment by the Gulf nation.
item.dc:creator: Fiona MacDonald, Dinesh Nair, Matthew Martin

media:content.media:description: Donald J. Trump in Doha on May 14. Photographer: Win McNamee/Getty Images

item.title: Hamas Says Aid Flows Must Resume After US-Israeli Hostage Freed
item.description: Hamas said it freed American-Israeli hostage Edan Alexander based on an understanding with the US that humanitarian assistance would return to Gaza and negotiations to end the war start immediately.
item.dc:creator: Sara Gharaibeh

media:content.media:description: Crowded tents in a temporary camp for displaced Palestinians in Gaza City, on Monday, May 5, 2025. Israel's security cabinet voted to intensify military operations in Gaza and call up of tens of thousands of extra reservists, while also deciding on a means of distributing aid in the Palestinian territory.

item.title: Denmark Considers Ending 40-Year Ban on Nuclear Power
item.description: Denmark is exploring adding nuclear power to its energy mix, potentially breaking away from a 40-year prohibition of the energy source, according to the Nordic country’s climate minister.
item.dc:creator: Sara Sjolin, Christian Wienberg

media:content.media:description: Lars Aagaard

item.title: Supreme Court’s Liberals Blast Trump Birthright Citizenship Plan
item.description: President Donald Trump’s executive order restricting the longstanding concept of birthright citizenship is probably illegal, the US Supreme Court’s liberal justices indicated during the first oral arguments in any of the numerous lawsuits challenging the Republican’s agenda.
item.dc:creator: Erik Larson

media:content.media:description: Demonstrators outside the US Supreme Court in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, May 15, 2025. The US Supreme Court is considering whether to allow President Donald Trumps executive order restricting the longstanding concept of birthright citizenship to start taking effect while a lawsuit proceeds.

item.title: Four in Five Canadians Believe Old US Relationship Is ‘Over,’ Poll Says
item.description: An overwhelming majority of Canadians believe the country’s relationship with the US has permanently changed, as President Donald Trump’s tariffs and sovereignty threats spark widespread fury in the northern nation.
item.dc:creator: Randy Thanthong-Knight

media:content.media:description: A "Product of Canada" sign near packaged meats at a grocery store in Langford, British Columbia, Canada, on Wednesday, Feb. 26, 2025. Furious Canadian consumers are boycotting American-made products and opting for domestic alternatives in response to US President Donald Trump's threats and actions.

item.title: GOP Tax Bill Seen Masking More Than $1 Trillion US Debt Hit
item.description: The cost of Republican lawmakers’ draft plan for sweeping tax cuts weighed in at $3.8 trillion over the next 10 years in one official estimate, a lowball projection that independent analysts say masks the true fiscal hit.
item.dc:creator: Enda Curran, Nancy Cook

item.title: EU Readies New Proposals in Push to Speed Up US Trade Talks
item.description: The European Union is revising its proposals for a potential trade deal with the US as the two sides move to accelerate serious negotiations, even though the Trump administration continues to provide little clarity and make demands that negotiators see as unrealistic, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: EU Commissioner for Trade and Economic Security, Maros Sefcovic arrives at the Europa building in Brussels, on May 15.

item.title: Deadly Clashes in Libya Risk Ending OPEC-Nation’s Relative Calm
item.description: Libya’s capital has been gripped by its worst fighting in years, sparking fears the North African nation will be dragged into widespread conflict as the government cracks down on rival militias.
item.dc:creator: Salma El Wardany

media:content.media:description: Destroyed vehicles following overnight clashes in in Tripoli, on May 13.
